description: From Anglo-Norman publik, public, Middle French public, publique et al., and their source, Latin pūblicus (“pertaining to the people”). Compare people.

adjectives.description: public (comparative more public, superlative most public)

entries.meaning: Able to be seen or known by everyone; open to general view, happening without concealment. [from 14th c.]
Pertaining to the people as a whole (as opposed to a private group); concerning the whole country, community etc. [from 15th c.]
examples: A mere 3% of the more than 1,000 people interviewed said they actually knew what the conference was about. It seems safe to say public awareness of the Convention on Biological Awareness in Nagoya - and its goal of safeguarding wildlife - is close to non-existent.

entries.meaning: Officially representing the community; carried out or funded by the state on behalf of the community. [from 15th c.]
examples: But culture's total budget is a tiny proportion of all public spending; it is one of the government's most visible success stories.

entries.meaning: Open to all members of a community; especially, provided by national or local authorities and supported by money from taxes. [from 15th c.]
examples: Some are left for dead on rubbish tips, in refuge bags or at public toilets.

entries.meaning: (of a company) Traded publicly via a stock market.
(not comparable, object-oriented programming) Accessible to the program in general, not only to the class or any subclasses.
The people in general, regardless of membership of any particular group.
examples: Members of the public may not proceed beyond this point.

entries.meaning: (public relations) A particular group or demographic to be targeted.
examples: To the extent that you will use them to reach many other publics, the news media will also be one of your publics.
